summary_medium:
Why This Book Matters

Traditional business planning assumes you can predict what customers want and execute against a plan. Startups face too much uncertainty for this approach. Eric Ries, drawing from his own startup failures, developed a scientific approach to building companies under extreme uncertainty.

Build-Measure-Learn

The core loop: (1) Build a minimum viable product (MVP), (2) Measure how customers respond, (3) Learn whether your assumptions are correct. Repeat as fast as possible.

The MVP isn't a prototype—it's the fastest way to start learning. A landing page, a concierge service, a video demo. Whatever tests your riskiest assumption with minimal effort.

Validated Learning

Startups exist to learn what customers want. Progress isn't measured by building features or shipping code—it's measured by validated learning about what creates value.

This means running experiments. 'We believe X will cause Y' becomes a testable hypothesis. If you can't measure it, you can't learn from it.

Pivot or Persevere

Armed with data, startups face a critical decision: pivot (change direction) or persevere (stay the course). Pivots aren't failures—they're corrections based on learning. Many successful companies pivoted: Instagram started as a check-in app, YouTube as a dating site.

Innovation Accounting

Traditional metrics (revenue, users) can be misleading early on. Instead, track actionable metrics that indicate whether you're building something people want. A/B tests, cohort analysis, funnel metrics.
summary_long:
Opening: Why Startups Fail

Eric Ries has seen startups fail up close—including his own. His first company, There.com, spent years building a virtual world with cutting-edge technology. They had great engineers, significant funding, and a solid vision.

They built something nobody wanted.

The conventional startup approach—write a business plan, raise money, build the product, launch—assumes you know what customers want. But in conditions of extreme uncertainty, you don't know what customers want until you test it.

The Lean Startup Principles

Ries proposes a scientific approach to entrepreneurship:

1. Entrepreneurs are everywhere: The methodology applies to anyone creating new products under uncertainty—startups, corporate innovation teams, nonprofits.

2. Entrepreneurship is management: A startup is an institution that requires a new kind of management designed for uncertainty.

3. Validated learning: Startups exist to learn how to build a sustainable business. This learning can be validated scientifically through experiments.

4. Build-Measure-Learn: Turn ideas into products, measure customer response, learn whether to pivot or persevere. Do this as fast as possible.

5. Innovation accounting: Measure progress with metrics focused on learning, not vanity.

The Build-Measure-Learn Loop

This is the core engine of the Lean Startup:

Build: Create a minimum viable product (MVP)—the simplest thing that lets you start learning. Not a prototype or beta version, but an experiment.

Famous MVPs:

• Dropbox: A video demonstrating the concept (no product yet)

• Zappos: Photographed shoes at stores and handled shipping manually

• Groupon: A WordPress blog with manually created PDFs

Measure: See how customers respond. Not opinions—behavior. Do they sign up? Do they use it? Do they pay? Do they come back?

Learn: What did you learn about your assumptions? Were they validated or invalidated?

The goal: minimize the time through this loop. The faster you learn, the faster you succeed—or fail cheaply and try something else.

Validated Learning

Learning is the essential unit of progress for startups. Not lines of code, not features shipped, not hours worked—validated learning about what creates customer value.

How do you validate learning? Through experiments:

'We believe [customer segment] will [behavior] because [reason].'

This becomes a testable hypothesis. Run the experiment, measure the results, update your beliefs.

Example: 'We believe parents will pay $10/month for a homework help app because they're frustrated with their children's academic performance.'

Test it. Build a landing page with that offer. Run ads to parents. See how many sign up. If they don't, you've learned something valuable—before spending months building the app.

The Minimum Viable Product

The MVP is probably the most misunderstood concept. It's not:

• A crappy version of your product

• A prototype

• The first release

It is: the fastest way to get through the Build-Measure-Learn loop.

What's the riskiest assumption in your business? Build only what's needed to test that assumption. Everything else is waste.

This requires courage. The MVP will be embarrassing. Ries's advice: if you're not embarrassed by your first version, you waited too long to launch.

Pivot or Persevere

Eventually, every startup faces a fundamental question: are we making progress toward our vision, or do we need to make a change?

A pivot is a structured course correction—changing one element of the strategy while keeping the vision. Types of pivots:

• Zoom-in pivot: One feature becomes the whole product

• Zoom-out pivot: The whole product becomes one feature

• Customer segment pivot: Same product, different customers

• Platform pivot: From application to platform (or reverse)

• Value capture pivot: Change how you make money

Pivoting isn't failure—it's evidence-based strategy. Many successful companies pivoted: YouTube, Instagram, Slack, Twitter.

The courage to pivot comes from validated learning. You're not guessing; you have data.

Innovation Accounting

Traditional metrics can hide learning:

• Total users (vanity metric) vs. usage per user (actionable)

• Total revenue vs. revenue per customer vs. repeat revenue

• Sign-ups vs. activation vs. retention

Innovation accounting uses metrics that answer: Are we building something people want? Are our improvements actually improving things?

Key technique: cohort analysis. Instead of looking at aggregate numbers, track how specific groups of users behave over time. Did users who signed up this month behave differently from last month? That tells you if you're learning.

Closing: Startups as Experiments

The Lean Startup reframes entrepreneurship from execution to experimentation. You're not building a company according to a plan—you're running a series of experiments to discover a sustainable business model.

This requires humility. Your vision might be wrong. Your assumptions probably are. But through rapid iteration and validated learning, you can find what customers actually want.

The goal isn't to avoid failure—it's to learn from failure as quickly and cheaply as possible.
